results.title: Escape to nowhere
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Surveys the general problem of drug abuse in Australia, pointing out the extent of dependence on alcohol, tobacco and various pharmaceutical preparations and the damage resulting from them as well as the use of illegal narcotics and hallucinogens

results.title: Four Corners: The Moonlight State
results.creator_credit: Shaun Hoyt and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Despite denials by the Minister for Local Government Russ Hinze, Police Commissioner Terence Lewis, and Police Minister, Bill Gunn, widespread police corruption is evident throughout Queensland. Brothels masquerading as massage parlours with illegal gambling inhouse and drug trafficking are shown. Persons prominent in the criminal activities are named. This program was a major contributor to the setting up of the Fitzgerald Enquiry into Corruption in Queensland. Presenter: Andrew Olle. Reporter: Chris Masters.
Episode of the ABC TV program Four Corners, aired 11/5/1987.

results.title: The Vanishing forest
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”
This film asks whether or not there should be an expansion in the woodchip industry. Using Eden and Coff’s Harbour as examples, the film presents some differing views on the value of woodchipping. A basic conflict over land use is raised and the viewers are left to make up their own minds.

results.title: The Wik, the law & the land (A)
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Latham and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
The Labor Government’s Native Title Bill was passed in December 1993, acknowledging the entitlement of the Aboriginal people, in accordance with their laws and customs, to their traditional lands. The High Court’s Wik decision in 1996 removed long held assumptions about land tenure in Australia and created uncertainty in the minds of pastoralists and miners. Aboriginal groups however, believed that the decision would have little impact and that the farmers were generally over-reacting. Co-existence in the form of upgraded land tenure for the pastoralists and traditional access to the land for the Aborigines could lead to long-term stability - at least that was the aim of the Cape York Agreement. The Federal Government under the leadership of John Howard, found itself coming increasingly under pressure from the National Farmers Federation to nullify the High Court’s judgement and extinguish native title. This program examines the issues. Reporter: Murray McLaughlin.

results.title: Beneath the veil (D)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
‘Beneath the veil’ charts British reporter Saira Shah’s terrifying journey into Afghanistan at the height of Taliban rule. After two decades of war and four years of Taliban rule, Shah’s documentary captures images of a country that has literally been blown to bits. Afghani citizens, especially women, live in a world of constant fear and terror. Legal public executions take place in front of thousands for crimes such as murder, adultery, prostitution and homosexuality. As a direct result of Taliban rule, woman and children without a ‘breadwinner’ in the family are forced to beg for food or starve. ‘Beneath the veil’ shows a country in moral meltdown, where the suffrage of humans is silenced by the paranoid demands of a fundamentalist religion in all its extremes. Contains graphic and disturbing images throughout with raw images of the daily life under the repressive regime, including public executions.

results.title: Minus thirteen and counting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
A probe into a growing social problem, the invasion of privacy resulting from developments in official and private surveillance of the individual. The title refers to Orwell’s novel, ‘1984’.

results.title: Sick at heart (A)
results.creator_credit: Debbie Whitmont and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
It is more than twenty five years since Aborigines were granted equal rights, but in that time the conditions in which they live have barely changed, and in many instances, because of the introduction of alcohol into their communities, their situation has become more hopeless. The appalling statistics on Aboriginal health - a male life expectancy less than that of Bangladesh, the highest risk of death by murder in the world, are a disgrace to Australia, and whilst there are those who care, there seems to be little hope for the future as whites and blacks alike despair of any easy solution. Paul Barry and the Four Corners team table this generally pessimistic report.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
It is more than twenty five years since Aborigines were granted equal rights, but in that time the conditions in which they live have barely changed, and in many instances, because of the introduction of alcohol into their communities, their situation has become more hopeless. The appalling statistics on Aboriginal health - a male life expectancy less than that of Bangladesh, the highest risk of death by murder in the world, are a disgrace to Australia, and whilst there are those who care, there seems to be little hope for the future as whites and blacks alike despair of any easy solution. Paul Barry and the Four Corners team table this generally pessimistic report.

results.title: The Business of change
results.creator_credit: Francoise Fombertaux and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Change, particularly technological change, has become an unavoidable facet of daily life. In this changing world of work, to accept change has become a business - “being motivated to be motivated”. Teaching “change” is the new profession and trained psychologists are now moving into the area of business coaching - they are the highly skilled agents of change. Manufacturing and agricultural industries have decreased and have been replaced by the service industry which currently employs over 70% of the entire workforce in Australia. Professional people who have more money than time are increasingly outsourcing services, eg house maintenance and cleaning, pet care (professional dog walkers). Corporate, big business, and government agencies use Call Centres to centralise their customer service facilities. This program discusses motivational coaching as a means of helping people deal with change. Reference is also made to Frederick W. Taylor’s theory on organisational change, or Taylorism. Reporter: Tony Barrell.

results.title: Deadly chemistry
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This video deals with the public health and safety risks associated with fires of toxic chemicals. In Australia a number of large storage sites for such chemicals are located close to populous suburban areas. Presented by Andrew Olle.

results.title: [U.S. of A.]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”
“Is this the way for future factories?” Documentary about a different sort of factory in the USA - Sol Air Corp - where there are no foremen or organised workforce, no production targets, average wages but many staff benefits including cheap petrol, medical and dental schemes and recreational facilities.
